item.title: LECTURE 1: Foundations of Ethical Practice
item.description:
Lecture Summary:

Ethical practice in psychological research did not emerge fully formed. It evolved through tension, crisis, and critical reflection. The contemporary landscape reflects a long-standing friction between regulatory systems shaped by biomedicine and the lived realities of social science research.

At the heart of this tension lies a mismatch. Biomedical ethics developed around a model focused on preventing physical harm, emphasizing protection and procedural control. Social science research, by contrast, often unfolds in fluid, relational, and context-sensitive environments. The resulting frustration—sometimes described as “ethics creep”—stems not from disagreement about whether ethics matter, but from disagreement about how ethics should be enacted in practice. Both regulators and researchers share the same premise: research must be morally justified. The challenge is moving from mere compliance toward intelligent, context-aware ethical conduct.

item.title: LECTURE 1: The Scientific Method in Psychology
item.description:
Lecture Summary:

We often rely on intuitive sayings to explain human behavior. Phrases like “birds of a feather flock together” and “opposites attract” both seem plausible—yet they contradict each other. This tension captures a central problem in psychology: commonsense explanations can justify almost any outcome after the fact, but they rarely allow us to predict behavior in advance.

Science emerges as a response to these limitations. Unlike intuition, scientific methodology is systematic and structured. Commonsense reasoning is vulnerable to confirmation bias (seeking only evidence that supports our beliefs), authority bias (accepting claims from high-status individuals without proof), and overconfidence. Errors such as the gambler’s fallacy—believing that independent events influence one another—demonstrate how easily human judgment deviates from probability and logic. Scientific thinking is designed to guard against these cognitive traps.

item.title: LECTURE 1: Introduction to Social Psychology
item.description:
Lecture Summary:

Why do people act the way they do? Are our behaviors driven primarily by personality, or are they shaped by the situations we find ourselves in? Social psychology begins with these deceptively simple questions and reveals that the answers are often more complex—and more unsettling—than common sense suggests.

At its core, social psychology is the scientific study of how people’s thoughts, feelings, and behaviors are influenced by the actual, imagined, or implied presence of others. This influence can be subtle, such as adjusting our opinions to fit a group, or extreme, as illustrated by historical tragedies like the Jonestown massacre. Such events demonstrate the profound power of social influence and the capacity of situations to override individual dispositions.

item.title: Welcome to your professor's blog!
item.description:
Hi, everyone!

I’m so excited to welcome you to my blog. Whether you’re looking for study materials, homework updates, or just a place to share ideas, this is where it’s all going to happen.

One of the best things about this blog is that it’s going to help us stay organized and connected without drowning in a sea of emails. Instead of sending out a bunch of messages that might get lost in the inbox, I’ll be posting lecture summaries, homework assignments, important announcements, reminders, and updates right here. That way, you’ll always know where to look for the latest info, and we can avoid any confusion or missed messages. The blog is designed to make your life easier, so you can focus on learning and collaborating without the stress of keeping track of a million different things.
